values: The future may become a bleak place. Fifty years have passed from now, and while much of what you know is the same, things are beginning to get much different. The media is still a prime powerhouse, and the invention of (and government limitation of) virtual reality doesn't seek to bring society back together. Meanwhile several radicals have gained huge amounts of political power, and by utilizing the most-advanced technology they seek to bring whole populations under their control. The climax of these tensions has just occurred, thousands of nuclear missiles knocking out communications and eliminating cities. And while most were stopped by orbital defense stations, the distraction it provided allowed the release of the strongest weapons: individual psychic powers. As an individual with psychic powers or weapons training, it is in your ability to decide the fate of civilization. We are a small RP site starting out, but we allow a high degree of freedom and our number of members should slowly increase. Everyone creates their own character from scratch, deciding history and what kind of powers they've acquired since the attacks. There are multiple factions you can work for, striding to save the world, destroy, or just figure out who's pulling all the strings. Come by and check things out! URL: http://www.prosperosgambit.proboards84.com Admin Contact: DarkSeerOfDreams on AIM/YIM, admin@rpdatabase.com for E-Mail/MSNIM

The Keys to Your Heart
You are attracted to those who have a split personality - cold as ice on the outside but hot as fire in the heart. In love, you feel the most alive when everything is uncertain, one moment heaven... the next moment hell. You'd like to your lover to think you are stylish and alluring. You would be forced to break up with someone who was insecure and in constant need of reassurance. Your ideal relationship is lasting. You want a relationship that looks to the future... one you can grow with. Your risk of cheating is zero. You care about society and morality. You would never break a commitment. You think of marriage as something precious. You'll treasure marriage and treat it as sacred. In this moment, you think of love as something you can get or discard anytime. You're feeling self centered.
What Are The Keys To Your Heart?

Unrelated:
You Are 21 Years Old
Under 12: You are a kid at heart. You still have an optimistic life view - and you look at the world with awe. 13-19: You are a teenager at heart. You question authority and are still trying to find your place in this world. 20-29: You are a twentysomething at heart. You feel excited about what's to come... love, work, and new experiences. 30-39: You are a thirtysomething at heart. You've had a taste of success and true love, but you want more! 40+: You are a mature adult. You've been through most of the ups and downs of life already. Now you get to sit back and relax.
What Age Do You Act?

The hero, left broken (his arm never heals right), is forced to beg for the next year, and move between jobs. He makes barely a living, and for the most part this is summarizied until the year ends. The only thing note-worthy is that there is one girl (in her late teens) who continually gives him money, despite the fact she too is poor. While this disturbs his now perputally paranoid character, he still accepts it.

Anyway, at the end of the year the girl finally buys him lunch, and there is a brief conversation. Also, while she steps out, a beautiful women confronts the hero and asks if he'd like a night with her. He forcefully rejects, and the girl has to shoo her away. Anyway, then in the next couple days the city under goes an industrilization, and a massive plant is set up. The hero flees to the next town.

There he encounters the beautiful women once again. Once again, she attempts to seduce him (although not quite in the exact way you might think; also, it fails partially because the man she's trying to seduce is blind) but this time he actually gets pissed off enough to hit her. Well, this causes the restless town to strike out against the blind man and the hero's forced to run off. He gets saved by the girl who fed him earlier, and she takes him to a small camp outside the city, where he meets her best friend (a young man) and her best friend's girlfriend. The hero sleeps overnight, but he wakes up before everyone else and leaves.

Why? Besides the obvious reasons (he's uncomfortable with them) he also ends up having a vision that the man who killed his friends is in the north/west/east/south (direction isn't determined, and really doesn't matter). He travels into the mountains, only to find the rebels (aka as the demons in the first chapter) fighting the army (aka the force you fought for earlier). He edges around the fightning, and ends up getting near the peak (partially because he senses a negative prefrence). As he arrives he finds a man with a large, silver/gold sword, who is know speaking in a booming voice. He speaks of eternal riches and how they will drown the enemy. Then to prove his point, he stabs the ground with his sword and, well, a circle around the stab suddenly melts, and out pours various liqiud metals. The great circle of metal then begins to ooze over, and the ground all around it cracks. The man is still safe in the middle, and he makes a small path to get back over.

Well, the hero then confronts him, and almost kills him. Almost. The man tumbles back into the wound of the earth he created, only to come out once again as a great gold golem, wielding a gigantic sword. The hero kills this demon, grabs the sword (now shranken back to its normal size) and begins to climb down the mountain during the ending battle. Well, he encounters the scythe-wielding man once again, and they have a very depressing conversation. The hero breaks down, but the man gives the hero back the soul of his friend. The soul then blesses the corrupted sword, essentially purginig it into a more holy sword. Anyway, both men leave.

The hero returns, but only the girl is still at the camp. Shes says her two friends went back to work, but she stayed behind to wait. The hero apologizes, but she doesn't mind. Minor dungeon on the way back, and then your back at the now more technologicaled city. While the two friends seem to have lost their old jobs, they got jobs at the new plant.

The hero stays at the girls house (along with the other two friends) for a few days, but they then all recieve news that there's going to be an attack against a nearby rebel camp during which the city will be flushed of rebels, while the rebel camp is also purged. Well, while the hero doesn't care his friends do, and they vow to leave the city, slow down the army, and warn the rebels. The hero doesn't agree (mainly because he was raised to hate the rebels) and leaves to kill the leader of the rebel camp (he doesn't reveal why he leaves to everyone else though).

The party of 3 begins to take off, but rumors circulate of the girlfriend being a rebel, and she is forced to stay behind. As the 2 take the path to the next city (not rebel held) our hero begins to cut through the forest. He quickly meets a higher-then-thou (personality wise) monk. The monk offers for them to travel together, and the hero doesn't care one way or the other.

The party of two precedes down the trail, through the town, and arrive at a mountain, all that stands between them and the camp. They know the army will take this route, and decide to cave-in most of the mountain to slow them down. Then while they're taking care  of that, the monk and the hero arrive at a massive wall of fire. The monk is horrified, and together the head into the flaming forest.

The party of two begin to evacute while the hero and the monk reach the top of the mountain the other two just passed through. There they find the cause of the fire. There stands a loud, passionate, pyromanic. He easily beats the monk sending him down the mountain, and then confronts the hero. The hero defeats him, but gets knocked out by heat stroke, and is rescued by the badly bleeding fire starter.

They all meet up at the city, with the rebels safely leaving and the army going around the mountain and through the burning forest. The sleep the night at the inn, but the hero has another vision and almost takes off alone. The boy (the one who's friends with the girl -- the girl being the current heroine) wakes up, and decides to tag along, leaving the girl with the fire starter.

I'll continue this in another post, but enjoy for now.

Again, all questions, comments and thoughts are apperciated, along with obvious cliches, confusing areas, and advice. If there's anything you think I should change tell me now when its still easy and I'm still willing too.

Oh, tell me if any of my quote of the days overlap. I don't really remember what I've used and what I haven't since I've read them all already.

QUOTE OF THE DAY:
"Ideas are like rabbits. You get a couple and learn how to handle them, and pretty soon you have a dozen." - John Steinbeck
http://17ark0racle.livejournal.com/14895.html

I have this habit of, when I feel bored I'll randomly create video games, with just a small or general plot, and then just do it to fill my time, moving on within the next day or too. I just do it to have fun (my larger projects tend to end up stressful, especially with how I get more people involved), but I figured I'd just write it all out here (because I feel like it, I guess).


Bah, anyway, it starts with the main character recieving a message from his nations capitol to take tests to see what kind of work he can get (such as soilder, smith, etc.) he happily accepts (or he has to, rather) and leaves his family, friend, and his teacher (who taught him combat, mainly guns and stealth) behind.

He returns only to find his village burning to the ground, and as he runs around the field of burning his houses, he encounters a cloaked man with a shining dagger. The man kills the teacher in front of our protagonist, and flees.

He finds his family and friends shaken, but alive, and they are all forced to move to the capitol city. While trying to set everything up again, our hero gets the results back, and it seems that they believe only he can find the 4 legendary crystals and save the world from a great demon. A government offical appears, who is supposed to help him, and out they go adventuring. Yadda yadda yadda, he journeys through 4 dungeons, and earns these 4 crystals. During this is three friends join him (all childhood friends, a boy and 2 girls. One girl is still a child at heart, and hasn't changed since when she first met our hero. The guy tends to get aggressive, and it seems he doesn't put friends first (although hes just human)) The other girl is pretty generic personailty, in the sense she's sweet, caring, and appears to be naive).

They then journey to the castle where the demon is supposed to lurk, along with an army.  They bust down the door and enter (the hero questions why they don't actually have the crystals with them, but the offical traveling with them hushes him). Anyway, they start slaughtering 'demons' and near the start the male friend leaves; he wants to split up to explore the castle, and he hopes that he can find riches to benefit them all. Eventually they arive in the inner sanctum, and encounter a large scythe wielding man. There's a massive fight as he unleashes his army (the fact their all human seeming never comes up. The hero is hushed about the non-demonic appearence of everything, and in the end he accecpts it all; anyway-) against the army the hero and the offical brought, and the offical rushes through to tackle the man. The man pulls out his dagger (scythe doesn't work that well in tight quarters) and after a struggle he kills the man. The offical screams how the hero should avenge his death against the beast, and as the army of the 'demon' dies off the hero reaches the man. The hero suddenly gets trapped in a position, and in moment of fear becomes a deer in the headlights. The man thrusts his dagger to kill him, but the heroine (the innocent one) jumps in front and gets her belly sliced open saving our protagonist. She rolls to the ground, and theres a brief scene of her eye contact with the now-crying man. There's also a non-seen scene, in which the man turns into the Angel of Mercy, and using his Scythe kills the heroine. On the players side she just closes her eyes and (clearly) passes on.

The other heroine (the one with peter pan syndrome) trys to pull the hero away and save him, but this angers him and he gravely wounds her with HIS dagger (guns aren't good close quarters either) and tears into the large man. He screams about how blind the hero is, and that the light has blinded him. He easily beats the hero into submission, and using his dagger, gouges out the hero's eyes before leaving.

The hero sits 'crying' on the ground, and the alive heroine shows up, only to break the hero's primary arm and leaves. The hero limps out of the now empty room and leaves the dungeon.

The hero's other friend shows up, and agrue vehmetly with the angry protagonist (about how he left them to die to 'death', the man with the sycthe). He almost fights him, but when he realizes his condition he just leaves. The hero limps out into the world, and so ends the first chapter.

Whoa, getting late. I'll do the second chapter later, probably. This turned up to be entertaining. Anyway, post comments thoughts if you want. Otherwise, um, don't.

I was pissed off when my dad said I was on my own thursday. For I had to either walk home or take the bus, and walking home already twice in the past couple monthes I thought 'what the hell, I'll take the bus. It shouldn't be too bad'.
Of course, I've never gone on a bus (not counting all those times when I was a wee young one) without SOMETHING going wrong. And this would be no diffirent.
To start things off, as soon as I got off campus, BAM I was lost. After awhile walking in a more-or-less random direction I figured out that I wasn't going to get to the bus stop I wanted to get too, but since I was close enough already to one that carried that same bus I figured what the hell. Well, see, this stop is farther down along the route, so already it was packed with students. And me and my goliath backpack (fucking school) had to stay up near the front. Okay, not so bad. Well, see, we weren't even at the next stop and some guy yells at me to get out of the way of this old lady (who I hadn't seen, as I was looking forward, and in swinging around I would probably kill 3 people). this wasn't so bad, but he thought I was some uncaring little teenage bastard, so I got pissed off. This caused my apologies to come off sarcastic, and he yelled at me more. I kinda had to restrain myself, and I just stopped doing anything (the old lady left the bus anyway).
Okay, now the bus cleared a little, and I was able to get my pack over one of the wheels (you know what those big grey things in front are). Still in front, now. The problem was though, that old guy was still there, and people had to squeeze past the both of us (I could barely move now). Then comes ANOTHER little old lady. Who clearly couldn't squeeze past us. And since that fucker didn't want to move, I sat down so that me and my backpack cleared outta the way. Then the guy next to me says I'm a cruel guy for taking that old ladies seat. Thank god a seat was empty across from me, and I said she could use that (guy still didn't believe me, and he took credit for the seat). I ended up talking to the guy, and it was actually a pretty nice conversation (still never really explained myself though). And after he left the remaining ride went fine.

Only now my hands smell like hobo.

Reading the <U>The Jungle</U> for outside reading (required english assignment which I know is due soon but I don't know the exact due date >_<) was not the best of choices. Besides being generally depressing, it gets you thinking.(Quick note, it was a book on immigrants working in the packing town of chicago about 100 or so years ago, but conditions were harsh, there was no minimum wage, and everybody was continually ripped off. It ended up creating the FDA, and the working requirement association, or whatever it's called.) I mean, maybe if you just thought it was all a thing of the past and it's all better it would be fine, but I'm sure there's some unknown injustice going on. Some are known, and nothing happens. And even if you think about, many people and businesses are unethical, and apparently we've have less free time then farmers from 100 BC had, will I'm sure our morale is even lower then back then. I'm beginning to think alot of the problems were kinda taken care of because religion created a system of ethics (although it all went down the crapper, most likely because the threat of divine punishment didn't work) and a way to offer insight. (On a side note, many Asian cultures did have more of an honor system, which is a reason crime is so low in places such as Japan.) But now it kind've has all disappeared. Life is very hard to survive, I mean I'm sure I'm luckier then so much people out there who starve their entire life, and at least I have a place to live. I know I shouldn't think about it, but I can't focus on homework.

Not that it really matters, and you probably don't care anyway.

I finally got up early today. Spring break has thrown off my waking hours. Although I was one of the few. My parents didn't get up until around noon. And then everyone at my house (other then myself) actually fell asleep again during the day >_<.

I wasn't that energetic myself. I was kinda all depressed and I just felt lonely. I wanted to get out and do something, but I didn't know what to do. It just seemed to be such a nice day. I find all overcast days that way. But alas. I just sat around. Didn't make much progress in anything. I think I did a few things, but I forgot. And honestly, I don't care, and you don't care.

I watched "Carch me if you can". Like the theme song. The movie's kinda intriguing too. It's always cool to think you'd do stuff like that, but really, you probably couldn't even if you tried. And you might get jailtime. Personally that scares me.

I hope it rains sometimes. Its always so calming when it rains. But I suppose that just makes me sad and lonely too. It just brings up hopes and memories... the past and the future...

QUOTE OF THE DAY:
"Since the social victim has been oppressed by society, he comes to feel that his individual life will be improved more by changes in society than by his own initiative. Without realizing it, he makes society rather than himself the agent of change. The power he finds in his victimization may lead him to collective action against society, but it also encourages passivity within the sphere of his personal life." - Shelby Steele
http://17ark0racle.livejournal.com/3309.html

I spent the day talking with friends until around 4:00, when I had to go put on a suit. Complete with frowny face bow-tie. I always hate dressing up, although I didn't bother complainig. I've learned to not bother fighting things you can't change. And it didn't really matter. I should dress up, and it actually wasn't that bad (although later on it gave me a sore toe and the bow-tie was a little tight).

We arrived early so my dad could set-up. I should have been bored, I mean I had nothing to do, but then, I wasn't really. I just kinda of went deep into thought. I guess when you get older you learn how not to be bored. You just can naturally enterain yourself. And really, it is always good to think. You need to stop and revalute your life once in awhile. Although it can certainly be depressing. Especially when you've done something wrong or made a bad call. I always wish I could do a retake. I ended up just thinking throughout the entire party, and just presenting myself. Go up to my dad so he could say "Here's my son, Christopher". That's the really the only reason I was there. A presentation piece.

Other then that it was just a fancy party. The food was awful, other then dessert, which was actually good, and the entree, which they served in such small quanities. There was no chaos either, which suprised me. Nothing went wrong. I don't know why, but it disappointed me. Maybe we live for chaos. I suppose it spices up our lives.

In the end I was tired as hell, and I just wanted to go home. I ended up feeling a little lonely too, just seeing my grandparents together, all happy, (in past photos) and how they used to be. I just was tired and depressed. I was still sick, too, and I felt awful. I don't know if I'll ever get better, really. My immune system is shot. Too much stress. No one understand's what I go through. But everybody says that. Maybe because it's true. Maybe it's just a human excuse.
